"They build their platform from the ground up, why can't they reap the benefits from that" has literally nothing to do with whether or not it's a monopoly or not or if it's good practice. They also forced a lot of other companies out of business or bought them to become the monopoly that they are, so no, not entirely from the ground up. It's not an argument for them having the right to do what they are doing. Apple engages in non-compete practices to force others out of the market and into using only their products. They then use that to force you into upgrades because of discontinued service, only using their repair shops and stupid things like a different charger for each new iteration so that you can't use old chargers and now you have to buy new ones. These are malicious practices made to take you for as much money as possible and if they could monopolize the entire marketplace they would. It also does not push them to make their product the best product because if they own a monopoly or have a captive audience via walled garden practices they actually can get away with less innovation because there is nothing comparable.

An easier way to understand it is internet service companies. They literally make agreements with each other so that only 1-3 services cover most areas meaning that they work together to force customers to have the least amount of options possible. That way they can all be bad options together, have the illusion of choice while they all providing bad rates. They force out smaller providers and monopolize the market. Monopolies can be acquired by a few companies, it does not inherently mean that only one company has it. Apple does the same thing, it's just more complex and a bit harder to understand because of it. Apple owns over 57% of the market in the USA which is more than it seems like because the android marketplace is diversified by multiple providers (Samsung being the next largest at 24%, less than half of Apple but still a gigantic number). They get to dictate the majority without sharing any of that diversity withing IOS.

Scalpers being an issue does not need to correlate with anecdotal physical violence either, they are still a problem to the point where on release many sets are not obtainable online and even with buy limits in stores lots of sets are sold out. Holiday event calendars were not available at any of the 8 nearest Lego stores near me for the entire month of December, none were available on amazon or online retailers either. There's no reason that a December set should be unavailable for the entire month of December. Again, just cuz you didn't see someone punching someone else over a Lego set does not mean that scalpers are not a problem.

Ask MandR: Would you consider the GWP Death Star II (40591), and the Nebulon-B Frigate (77904) to be part of the Midi Scale/Starship collection? A friend and I are debating it, and he says their promotional status and limited availability exclude them from being a part of the collection, and I say everything has limited availability and their size and the fact that they were released within close proximity to the other sets make them part of the collection.

I think comparing Apple taking a huge percentage off of other stores/platforms running on apple devices against the will of those platforms is a pretty poor comparison to Lego obtaining a bunch of Nintendo licenses because Nintendo wants Lego sets of their merchandise.

I think calling Lego a monopoly is kind of strange too, because while they're dominant in the toy aisle they're nowhere near the entirety of what's available in the toy aisle. They're not the only company making toys for any of their licenses. At most you could say they're dominating the interlocking brick system market, though as far as I'm aware they're not actively trying to squash smaller brands or make their system incompatible like most monopolies.

"Scalping" as a word is pretty much meaningless. "Resale" is not an issue or something to be opposed. It's the reason that Lego or Pokemon do not lose 80% of their value instantly after your purchase; because at any time, you can "cashout" or resell.

Huge companies, especially Lego, are very bad at lead times and accurately assessing consumer demand. Just look at Fortnite sets 10yrs too late üòÇ

I've owned my house for over a decade now and you're spot on with your take on home ownership - it all adds up, little by little, even things you don't think will add anything.  Good example is I wanted to buy a shed so I can store lawncare stuff, foldable chairs, etc - you know the stuff you want to have around but don't use all the time.  This will free up space in the house which will make it easier to play Tetris with the remaining stuff inside the house - make it look nice.  But now you have an extra building that needs attention - cleaning, repair, general maintenance.  Something that made your life easier suddenly adds a whole other layer of responsibility to your life.  It's the way of the world I suppose.

Regarding the color of Jango and Boba's jumpsuits, I'm not sure they're inaccurate to the entire source material so much as they're inaccurate to those promo shots specifically. On Geonosis Jango appears to have a more lavender jumpsuit, but on the Slave I it looks more blue. In behind the scenes material it's said that there were several Jango Fett costumes, so maybe some of them were more blue and some were more purple. And who's to say which material LEGO was given to work with to determine the proper source material color. If he was wearing a blue suit on the Slave I, it would be most accurate to give him a blue suit when paired with the Slave I set. Either way it's certainly not just a LEGO problem, you can find action figures and pictures of Jango in both blue and purple, and you can find forum posts of people asking which is the right color.

Ask M&R: Do you think one of the reasons Lego is constantly cutting ends with Star Wars minifigs is because the Star Wars license may work in a different way than others? Maybe Star Wars in 2019 saw that some minifigs were reselling for hundreds of dollars on Bricklink, which in the past wasn‚Äôt a problem, but now Lego owns and makes profits from all of those sales. So they went to Lego to rework their contract where they make a certain % of the expected minifig value.
For example:
The Rebels from the Tantive hallway are valued at $2.25, and if Star Wars made 25% of that value, they would get $0.48.
But let‚Äôs say Lego wanted to give those minifigs dual molded legs, and that was projected to add $1.50 value to that figure. Even if it only cost Lego an extra 5 cents to make them, they would now owe Star Wars $0.98 per fig, almost double. I have no idea how much Star Wars is actually making from Lego, its just a theory I had.

Whenever I brought up the fact that graphic designers put flats up on the wall for reviews people always said I was nuts. That book shows the process. With all the comments & revisions written on the flats or sticky notes. The brand managers / marketing team make comments as well as the creative team. It‚Äôs an extensive process. Usually they have 3 rounds of reviews as well. That‚Äôs why sometimes the designs can change to stuff us fans complain about. I know cause I‚Äôve had to put flats up on the wall. It‚Äôs an industry standard process with most graphic design jobs. It‚Äôs always frustrating when a marketing director makes a comment the designer doesn‚Äôt agree with. That how bad fig art can happen üòÜ. Great episode Ryan. üëç
